Variations notwithstanding, there are basically two kinds of tournament reports. One aims mainly at presenting interesting or instructive deals, the other at reporting and accounting for the results. Although he was not the

sole inventor of any techniques, Edgar brought new dimensions to both varieties. To the "good deals" type, he added the common-theme approach nowadays typically applied in non-reportorial articles. For an illustration, let's look at some snatches from the thematic report of his atypical triumph in the Individual, from the March, 1957, issue of The Bridge World.

**Life Masters Individual**

*by Edgar Kaplan*

**W**hile I enthusiastically approve of the result of this year's Masters Individual, I can't say that I had a very good time playing in it. And I usually do. This is a nerve-shattering tournament if you're in a good position to win. I could never relax and really enjoy the mad scramble. [*Editor's note (by Moyse): It has, perhaps, been subtly indicated that Mr. Kaplan was the winner of this year's Masters Individual, with its record-breaking field of 136, but we like to make everything pellucidly clear: He was.*]

There are three factors in the winning of this event: you must play reasonably well; you need a lot of fortitude; and you must be enormously lucky. Luck is the theme of this article, as it should be in one about the Individual.

There are many kinds of good luck in bridge, and I had all of them. In this first hand I was lucky enough to have my partner make an excellent play. (In this event, in which even the best players produce their worst bridge, this is the very height of luck.)
I was South, playing with Geoffrion, of Montreal. . . .
. . . a well-deserved top for my partner, a lucky top for me.
Another Canadian, Eric Murray, of Toronto, also earned an excellent score for me with accurate play, but he was my opponent. . . .
. . . This last hand was the luckiest of all. It came up in the final session, and the tournament hinged on the outcome.

**MASTER SOLVERS:** For the 1997 Yearly Honor Roll, send your yearly total, name and address on a piece of paper separate from other correspondence in the same letter. Please *do not* put it on the same sheet as monthly answers. If you missed a month, use the average of your other 11 scores for that month and so state. If your score exceeds 8250, please indicate month-by-month totals. If you scored zero on any problem in September, October, November or December, list the problem and your action.

**Deadline: February 10, 1998.**

That seems to say he is prepared to defend five diamonds if LHO bids it. But not,
CARL HUDECEK: "Four hearts. And, unless pard doubles, I'm bidding five hearts over five diamonds."
KIT WOOLSEY: "Four hearts. Let the opponents make the first wrong guess. We know we will want to compete to at least four hearts anyway, so why not bid it now?"
STEVE WEINSTEIN: "Four hearts. I may miss a slam—but four diamonds gets us there too often, and two notrump is invitational to three diamonds for the opponents."
BOBBY WOLFF: "Four hearts. Preemptive value is quite often worth more than science."

Normally, we love to sign off with Bobby, ever the voice of reason.

However, we need to go to the co-author of the previously mentioned book.
AL ROTH: "Two clubs. I know the bidding will continue, and I hope I will learn what is best later."
And one panelist who is exhibiting increased paranoiac symptoms,
EDDIE KANTAR: "Redouble. I don't know how many points I'll get for this one."
Don't you know that you need 10 HCP to redouble? Not to worry: We'll give you 10 here, making your two-problem total 110.

**Problem C**

IMPs; E-W vul. You, South, hold:
What call do you make?

A continuation of the last problem's exercise in obstructionism. Our vulnerable opponent has opened two clubs. In the modern style we think that,

♠ A K Q x x x x ♥ K Q x ♦ A x ♣ x,

is plenty good enough. Of course, you could be playing against Ira Rubin, who might not open two clubs even with another ace. (We hear that he can't remember the last time he opened two clubs on a distributional hand.)

The four-diamond bidders believe they are doing their all. The three-diamond bidders must live under a black cloud to be so pessimistic, and we can't say what we think of the two-diamond bidders, at least not until we give them a chance first.

JOHN CARRUTHERS: "Two diamonds. This looks kind of wimpish, but no jump is suitable with such a good hand. Why would I want to go high when it's possible they can't make anything? And neither three nor four gets the message across. Just because I don't jump does not mean I don't have extra length."
We believe that last sentence contained a triple-negative (we play only double-negatives).
